repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
It should be safe to block for the GIL while holding the lock provided we never do it the other way around (which we don't because we control access to the lock). That probably makes things worse if you're mixing locking with and without the GIL, but it does at least mean that you eventually succeed.

Add a manual benchmark that can be used to measure it. I don't think it makes sense as an automatic benchmark because you're interested in both wall-clock time and CPU time, but it was useful while investigating this.

I also note that in some cases (very contended, with both timeouts set to 0) the PyMutex never seems to finish. This isn't something we can really control but arguably it might be worth documenting.

Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/7023 and the comment https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6579#discussion_r2176556402

comment_data.body: Probably fine, just wanted to note that `PY_LOCK_ACQUIRED` is part of an enum also in PyPy, so `defined()` will not usually prevent the override. We could add a version guard for PyPy < 7.3.20, though future enum value changes are very unlikely here.
Can we avoid this dance (at least in some cases) by passing the current (sometimes) known GIL state into the call?

We do (by calling a different function rather than as an argument)

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/c253f8952bfe36e755226d9cfe8c8d5fe62791b2/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L9169-L9176

Ok, so this is called from `nogil` functions that don't know if they own the GIL – but they probably don't because that's the main reason to declare the function `nogil` in the first place. Then trying to acquire it and accidentally releasing it if it was owned, as you do above, seems the right tradeoff to me.

commit.message:
Improve heavily contended PyThreadType lock

It should be safe to block for the GIL while holding the lock
provided we never do it the other way around (which we don't
because we control access to the lock). That probably
makes things worse if you're mixing locking with and without
the GIL, but it does at least mean that you eventually
succeed.

Add a manual benchmark that can be used to measure it. I
don't think it makes sense as an automatic benchmark because
you're interested in both wall-clock time and CPU time, but
it was useful while investigating this.

I also note that in some cases (very contended, with both
timeouts set to 0) the PyMutex never seems to finish. This
isn't something we can really control but arguably it might
be worth documenting.
Fix PyPy, improve warning, improve deadlock avoidance
